rename.to: we likely need to keep some mention of postgresql 8.2 around to have nominal redshift support

body: @CaselIT  in db08a699489 we bumped PG support to 9 and reenabled this query however the "8.2 " thing  is also relied upon by redshift.  I'm not sure what the status of https://pypi.org/project/sqlalchemy-redshift/ is on this but they very possibly rely upon it also

**Mike Bayer** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **main** branch:

**restore nominal "<8.2" checks to assist with redshift** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/4496
sorry, looks like I accidentally caused this issue to be closed, reopening.

Since there is an external redshift dialect, I'm not sure why should the internal pg dialect accommodate things for it?

It's easy enough to override that logic in the external dialect.

FWIW, the external redshift dialect doesn't support SQLAlchemy 2.0.0+ 
https://github.com/sqlalchemy-redshift/sqlalchemy-redshift/issues/264
and currently requires the use of SQLAlchemy < 2.0.0
```
ERROR: pip's dependency resolver does not currently take into account all the packages that are installed. This behaviour is the source of the following dependency conflicts.
sqlalchemy-redshift 0.8.12 requires SQLAlchemy<2.0.0,>=0.9.2, but you have sqlalchemy 2.0.0 which is incompatible.
```

I know this isn't really your "problem" but it might factor into any solution that depends on the external dialect.
sqlalchemy-redshift needs to take this on

I'm currently looking into making this fix downstream for `sqlalchemy-redshift` but I can't really see any sane way to override this behaviour as it stands without copy-pasting several layers of upstream initialization code from `sqlalchemy` and `psycopg2`.

I was hoping we might reconsider reopening this in order to refactor those lines out into a method we can use as a dialect-specific override hook for the backslash escapes logic, as Federico suggested in the now-closed PR: 

https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/4496/1/lib/sqlalchemy/dialects/postgresql/base.py

I've contributed to sqlalchemy-redshift before but never to sqlalchemy so not sure what the contibution guidelines are, but I'm happy to supply a PR with this change if that would be helpful?
@CaselIT referred to creating a new method to "set_backslash_escapes" so we can accept a PR for this refactoring

issue.title: Add override hook PGDialect.set_backslash_escapes()
issue.body:
### Description
Refactor out the lines in `PGDialect.initialize()` that set backslash escapes into their own method to provide an override hook for [`sqlalchemy-redshift`](https://github.com/sqlalchemy-redshift/sqlalchemy-redshift) to use.

Fixes #9442

### Checklist

This pull request is:

- [ ] A documentation / typographical error fix
	- Good to go, no issue or tests are needed
- [x] A short code fix
	- please include the issue number, and create an issue if none exists, which
	  must include a complete example of the issue.  one line code fixes without an
	  issue and demonstration will not be accepted.
	- Please include: `Fixes: #<issue number>` in the commit message
	- please include tests.   one line code fixes without tests will not be accepted.
- [ ] A new feature implementation
	- please include the issue number, and create an issue if none exists, which must
	  include a complete example of how the feature would look.
	- Please include: `Fixes: #<issue number>` in the commit message
	- please include tests.

body: ok, let's reopen this to support that logic

**Matt del Valle** has proposed a fix for this issue in the **main** branch:

**Add override hook PGDialect.set_backslash_escapes()** https://gerrit.sqlalchemy.org/c/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/+/4508

issue.title: support sqlalchemy 2.0
issue.body:
sqlalchemy 2.0 was released earlier this month. https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/dialects/ we should work to support it. 

- read sqlalchemy's docs to understand breaking changes between 1.4 and 2.0
- identify what parts of our existing code need to be refactored to support 2.0 while maintaining support for 1.4
- identify what new 2.0 features need support in our dialects
- expand upon tests based on new apis in 2.0
